paragraphs.text: An evil corporation is a trope in popular culture that portrays a corporation as ignoring social responsibility, morality, ethics, and sometimes laws in order to make profit for its shareholders.[1] In rare cases, the corporation may be well intentioned but extremist, engaging in noble cause corruption.

paragraphs.title: In fiction
paragraphs.text:
The notion is "deeply embedded in the landscape of contemporary cultureâ€”populating films, novels, videogames, and more." The science fiction genre served as the initial background to portray corporations in this dystopian light.[1]

Evil corporations can be seen to represent the danger of combining capitalism with larger hubris.[2]

paragraphs.title: In real life
paragraphs.text:
In real life some corporations have been accused of being evil. To guard against such accusations, Google at one point in its history had the official motto "Don't be evil",[1] however they abandoned that motto for being too obviously frivolous.[3] The New Yorker wrote that "many food activists consider Monsanto (now Bayer) to be the definitively evil corporation".[4]

The Debate over Corporate Social Responsibility wrote, "For many consumers, Wal-Mart serves as the evil corporation prototype, but record numbers shop at the stores for low prices."[5]

In Japan, a committee of journalists and rights activists issues an annual "corporate raspberry award" known as Most Evil Corporation of the Year Award (also called the Black Company Award) to a company "with a culture of overwork, discrimination and harassment".[6]
